text: hello my name is Steve lurman and I'll be giving a 15minute lecture and then uh
what I'll try to do during this lecture is give you a broad overview about some of the Innovations in the educational
uses of Technology let me first introduce myself a little um I am a professor at MIT I've been here about 26
years and I currently direct an interdisciplinary Research Center called the center for educational Computing
initiatives this is a center that cuts across all of MIT schools and departments and tries to undertake
Innovative research in how different Technologies computer Technologies and Communications Technologies can be used
in educational settings most of our work is in higher education but occasionally we do do projects that go beyond that
scope what I thought I would do is first give you uh a little bit of a sense of
some of the opportunities that we as a group uh have been exploring and they really have to do about changing how we
think about teaching and learning and so I've shown a slide up here uh which
contrasts two different ways of thinking uh on the left side as you look at it
are what might think of as more traditional ways of thinking about educational processes and on the right
side are some of the ways in which we want to transform that thinking so for example we often talk in about teaching
and I'd rather focus more on learning what the student learns rather than what the teacher teaches rather than thinking of a
teacher necessarily one could think of an individual who acts more like a mentor or coach in certain settings
students uh are really Learners they may not be students in the formal sense they can be people in Industry trying to
acquire new skills they can be individuals at home we normally think of teaching as a synchronous process you
and I are in the same place at the same time while we're learning when in fact at least right now we're not I'm
teaching this uh lecture or this piece in a uh Studio here at MIT and you're
watching it somewhere else at a totally different time so a lot of teaching and learning can be thought of as less as a
synchronous activity and more of an asynchronous one too much of education at least in my view is passive we put
students in classrooms or in lecture halls in higher education and we talk to them there's been a strong move to
changing that relationship where the student becomes far more active an active participant in his or her own
learning and we also uh have gone very much from a scheduled learning there are
classes at certain hours to much more ability to learn on demand when you need it where you need it and finally uh we
often think of a set of materials for teaching there's a set of lecture notes that we hand out to students for example
and it's actually now much more interest in focusing on students working towards some goal now no single transformation
we're working on has all these attributes simultaneously but they represent for us a direction that the
research lab I direct is trying to head in and I thought the best way to illustrate some of that was to talk a
little about some of the projects the work that goes on at the center for
educational for Center for educational Computing initiative CCI really falls
into three different intersecting areas one area is enabling Technologies
not all of the technologies that we need to help people learn better are necessarily available today and so
there's some element of the research that looks at technology that can help students in different ways things that
enable ways of new teach ways of learning and teaching a second broad
area is applications building realworld educational software and Communications
Technologies and applying them to with actual learners most of the activity we
do in my Center in fact falls into this area of Applied research looking at
opportunities for how we might improve education building things that help students and then putting them in
classroom settings the third area is one I think of as evaluation or assessment
as it's sometimes called and that really gets at the question fundamentally so
what if the goal is to improve education then one has to ask hard questions about
does a technology actually help do people actually learn differently or better or faster and even that's not
sufficient the types of questions one has to ask really are much more fine grained who learns better what types of
materials are better taught with a particular technology than by conventional means how much does it cost
both to create the Technologies and to use them how does that compare with traditional educational settings and so
it's not sufficient simply to do things and argue and wave one hands and say but we think that works many of the projects
we do have fairly detailed assessment plans associated with them where the goal as best as possible is to make some
inferences about learning outcomes and how both students and teachers uh use
the materials to effectively help the students learn well with that I'd like to tell you about a couple of the projects going
on in my lab not all the projects are ones I direct uh myself the first
example I want to give you is directed by Professor Peter Donaldson he is uh
the head of the literature section at MIT and a Shakespearean scholar and he's been working in a Project based in my
lab uh he's directing this project for actually several years which is an attempt to give students access as part
of the educational process to a much wider array of materials that they can use to help learn uh about Shakespeare
and his work they call this project the Shakespeare electronic art archive and
while I'll only be able to tell you a few things about it right now I'd actually like to illustrate by a very simple example one of the things that
Professor Donaldson wants to do is to give students exposure to the fact that
the shake body of Shakespearean literature the plays in this case uh which he focuses on primarily is not
really a fixed body that is there's no single authoritative version of The
Shakespearean plays in fact these were living plays they were plays that people
performed that Shakespeare himself probably changed we do not have anything
written in Shakespeare's own handwriting that is we don't know what he wrote what we do know is what was published some of
it contemporaneously during his life and they're actually multiple versions of
some of the plays and perhaps the most famous of all lines in one of the plays is from Hamlet and in a version the
printed version called the first folio Edition Hamlet says to be or not to be that is
the question this is the line that those of us who grew up in English speaking world all learned and that was the way
we all thought about Hamlet but what Professor Donaldson tries to do is make students aware uh that there are
multiple versions and so what he's done is digitized the some of the existing
copies of the earliest printed work of Shakespeare and so uh slide you can look
at now has uh the first folio Edition slide and this is i' actually a
digitized version at high resolution of that particular quotation from Hamlet and then it goes on in the normal way
well it turns out that there's another Edition called the first quto edition which uh in its earliest printed version
actually predating the folio Edition uh says to be or not to be I there's the
point it's a different line from the one that we've all learned and what Professor Donaldson wants to do is
explore the subtle questions about well first of all which is right well the answer probably is both uh at various
times these were performed why are they different how did they come that to be different what might have happened we
don't know for certain but what might have happened to lead to these two Divergent additions now if you look at
the quos and and folio additions there are many cases where there's significant Divergence not so much necessarily in a
single line but in fact groups of lines the quto are highly condensed the folio
additions probably come closer to the full play but what he wants to do not so much is tell the students what's right
or wrong but stimulate a very different discussion revolving around these close
to original Source materials this is the best that we have in terms of source materials and so he's actually created
digitized editions uh of all the plays that is the full first folio and the
first quto and actually there's another round of Publications called the second quto edition he's gotten access to the very small
number some of the very small number of these that actually exist today and he's got created high resolution digitized
versions of them with permissions of the owners and he uses those as discussion materials and then he's carefully index
those against uh things like the Oxford English edition of the plays and so what
he's created is a highly linked uh set of materials that can serve as the
foundation for a very different discussion would that would normally go on in a Shakespeare course this is a
screen that you'll probably have trouble seeing uh right now but this is an example of the complete interface you
get at these materials through a web browser and what I wanted to illustrate here on the right side you'll see uh
part of a performance in addition to looking at the plays he's digitized versions of the actual performances of
the plays focusing particularly on Hamlet and he's been able to get access to a whole range of Hamlet performances
including some that that aren't even in English one of them is a Swedish performance and so he's able to link the
text to the plays to performances of those plays and then compare how different actors have interpreted
important roles this then leads to a very different discussion because a play is not a piece of text a play is a
living thing that is meant to be performed by actors in a particular setting different actors with different
directors interpret the words of Shakespeare to the best we can reconstruct those words differently and
he wants to bring early in students education this idea then finally he's
also brought together a body of thousands of pieces of art that relate to The Shakespearean plays some of this
is contemporaneous to Shakespeare's time the Elizabethan era and then others are renderings of various plays in different
time periods when they were performed or pictures of different actors or different settings and so he's able to
bring to bear a rich extensive body of materials to talk about uh Shakespeare
with his students another project is something we've been working on uh which tries to
bring together a collection of film about modern China when I say modern
China I really mean Revolution and later China we've been working with a film company called Longbow Productions
longbo is a independent documentary film production company that does perhaps the
best uh independent documentaries about China they've won SE many awards in their work
uh and they have graciously made available their complete film Library not just the documentaries that they
produce themselves but the films uh that they used before they cut together the
documentary for every hour of documentary there might be a hundred more hours of source video and film and
they've agreed to allow uh us to work with them they of course still own the film but to digitize portions of it and
to then uh create on the internet various uh representations of that so
people can search this archive and we've been working with them we've developed what I would call a prototype we have
not yet done a complete project but I wanted to show you some pieces of this
uh on slides so one of the things we've done is created a searchable archive and
what we've done with them and actually they did most of the work on creating these IND indexes uh has created a two-
tiered indexing hierarchy there's a set of topic areas things like actions
places people uh education history festivals and for each of those
categories we've created a set of keywords and we've indexed portions of
their film collection uh against those keywords down to small segments so a
single documentary might have as many as 20 to 50 to 100 segments Each of which
was indexed separately so this is uh the search screen and so a user can put
together a search uh across various uh topics for example uh one of the
documentaries they did had a segment that went into a uh Village a rural Village and interviewed many of the
older women uh who had of course grown up as young girls before the Revolution
and these were women who had gone through the traditional footbinding that had was uh not uncommon in preau China
and they talk about both the ceremony and the effects on them and how it was perceived and why they did it and what
their parents thought and these interviews are also translated and so one might be very interested in studying
that to understand preow pre-revolution rural China and these materials allow
students to go in and look at those sorts of questions here is a result from that search uh we call a sample of the
media every piece of media every small video clip uh eventually every picture
or image has a set of Records associated with it and this is a summary of the set
of Records so the student gets a summary about the record where it came from that's what documentary or what part of
a larger piece of film or video it came from and then and most importantly they
watch that sample of media there's a little video player on the right side of the screen that allows the student or
the professor teaching from these materials to bring up those materials and show the students so this allows the
students to explore these materials on their own asynchronously to do research
basically into these materials another thing they have done is created what they call tours and
Professor uh Peter Purdue has been working on this he's uh in the history section of the MIT uh Humanities
department and Professor Purdue has created from these materials what we're calling tours a tour is a organized walk
basically not a physical walk but a virtual walk through a collection of materials and so what he's done is
organized subsets of the Longbow collection into
meaningful multimedia essays and so here is a uh tour a screen from a tour we put
together about tenen square tenan square has enormous historical significance in
China it's of course the place the Revolution was declared by Mao it was the place for the de pro-democracy
Uprising uh that most of us are familiar with uh and it has a central place in the political and economic history of
China and so what he's done is organized a a basically an essay around the
geography of tanam and square this is a highly stylized on the left side of the screen
a highly stylized view of the square and then students can move around through
that and as they do they get segments of a longer essay that has text and video
and still images and so here once they're in the tour and they're in the Square they can read this hyperlink
essay which has text and each part of the essay has link LS to various media
that are also in the archive in this mode either the student can self-study work on their own his or her
own or uh often Professor Purdue will use these materials in the classroom and
use them to launch a disc a larger discussion uh about what the students understand from these
materials a third project i' like to tell you about is in physics uh for
those of you who are not from MIT all MIT students have to take two semesters
of physics all undergraduate students and for many students this is the most
rigorous exposure to physics they have ever had in the first semester of physics they study what basically might
think of n neonian mechanics this turns out at the pace we teach it to be a difficult subject for
some group of students and Professor Richard Larson working with Professor
Walter Leen who actually teaches this course uh many times has taught in the past have been developing something
called pivot which is the physics interactive video tutor the pivot
project is an attempt to bring together a very large highly interl set of
materials to help students who are trying to learn newtonium mechanics and what they've done is
they've assembled a very extensive collection of video and text and
graphics and other materials index them against the flow of the actual course
itself so as the course moves from lecture to lecture each lecture corresponds to a set of
keywords in addition uh they've done things like videotaped help sessions
Professor Luen uh gives uh basically hourlong help sessions during most weeks
in a help session what he might do typically is solve between four and
eight different problems that illustrate the key principles being taught that
week these are problems that look a lot like what you might have to do in during their during your weekly assignment if
you were a student in this course so Professor Luen uh goes through each of these examples and solves the problems
and talks about the issues and strategies and solving them and how they might actually relate to homework
assignments that the students are trying to do uh during that week the video
tutor also has a couple of elements but before telling you about those let me sort of
go through some of the hypotheses that we have uh and that we're now testing
about why these uh this subject is difficult and why these materials
assembled as we have assembled them might be useful the first is physics is difficult for many students and so they
need uh to have much more ability to go over certain subjects again and again uh
ideally they each would have their own personal tutor and that of course is not possible with hundreds of of students
taking this each semester students who even don't have any difficulty uh we believe could learn
in much deeper ways if they had access to a tutor who could present things in different ways to
them uh the traditional mode of teaching these materials the lecture hall We
Believe has very low what might think of as bandwidth that is it tends to be a one-way flow of communication from The
Faculty to the student it's highly confined students have limited opportunity to ask questions the whole
lecture lasts 50 minutes three times a week and so the lecturer is generally
forced to move at a pace that works for the typical student which tends to be a
little slow for the very talented student and uh too fast for the less talented or less uh student who's less
familiar with the materials I ideally students be ought to be able to navigate through this material in ways that best
suit their own pace and also the reality is that in
large classes students have limited face-to-face contact with the teacher they can go to office hours there are
recitation sections in smaller groups but the truth is that for the most part
most students learn in a relatively passive way well what pivot tries to do do is
change that by providing a efficient economical uh collection of very rich
media what we've done is we take these problems these help sessions we've digitized videos of all the lectures is
about a typical semester between 36 and 39 lectures we have taken a textbook uh
one of the published textbook and created an electronic version of that and then the most important important
thing to do is that we've linked all these materials together so they are searchable in addition uh one of our
graduate students Stephen Nim has been working on agents software agents which
is a category of software that watches what people do and say what watches what people say they want and makes forward
predictions and does things that would be useful for the student in this case or whoever is using them so one of the
So-Cal the agents software agents that Steve Nim has developed watches what
students have used in the pivot collection and then Combs through the
collection and makes predictions about what additional things in the collection
the student would find most useful at that moment so for example if the
student is looking uh at material that uh is very advanced in a particular
field say angular momentum uh the T the tutor would look ahead and say okay I
can find other materials that have the quality that they're highly Advanced that is they're not more introductory
and that they deal with angular momentum if on the other hand another student is looking through the pivot collection and
is focusing most of his or her time on the more introductory or
prerequisite parts of the collection the videos and other materials then the
tutor will begin to identify that as a characteristic and at least for the next
few uh sessions would be presenting uh possibilities that the student could
choose that match those criteria so for each student the tutor builds a model of
that student's current state what they what the tutor thinks they know and doesn't know and tries to present to
that student options that best meet what the tutor thinks are the students uh needs
at that moment so uh pivot has a software agent that guides the learner uh this agent
keeps track of the student from session to session and offers advice to the
student the last thing I thought I would tell you about is uh a broader look at
educational technology at MIT MIT has something called the Council on educational technology this is a council
appointed by Robert Brown the proost and has been meeting periodically to try to
help guide MIT in a long-term strategy for how to use educational
technology this uh has been looking at a broad range of strategic options basically this is the place where MIT as
a university tries to look ahead and to determine what things make the most
sense for us as a university in the area of educational technology and the challenge here is that this is turns out
to be an area where there are probably many more options than we should or
could pursue the problem and the wonderful thing and both the problem and wonderful thing about new technologies
in education is that it opens up a vast array of possibilities no one
organization be it MIT or a public school or a for-profit university could
possibly try all of them in any effective way and so everyone in this field is trying to look ahead and decide
given the strengths and weaknesses of their organization what small subset of
the entire range of possibilities should they pursue the Council on educational
technology at MIT has been doing that for MIT we've had help from a couple of Consultants who've actually volunteered
their time McKenzie and boo Allen and Hamilton have both been participants in this process and what we've been trying
to do is isolate a few key areas that it makes sense for MIT to explore intens ly
now some of the challenges first are that the technology advances quickly and students and professors have shifting
expectations the generation of students that are coming to universities today have essentially grown up with the
internet in some ways they're the first generation where the internet has been part of their life in their formative
years for most of us people of my age the internet came later it's something we learned later but it wasn't part of
our our Early Educational experiences today's students and particularly the ones arriving now in
the next uh in this decade the internet has been with them most of them not all of them have had access to the internet
uh throughout their at least uh middle and high school years and so they're used to using it as a resource for
better or worse now in addition there have been several universities that have responded
to these opportunities with a for-profit model that is they've spun off subsidiary units that some cases are
profit making uh and the question of course for all universities is has this been a sensible thing to do and for MIT
does it make sense for us MIT has undertaken a variety of experiments in educational technology
but we really feel at this point in time we need some sort of coordinated strategy what we've decided and
recommended actually we this is not a decision-making body and much as an advisory body to the senior
administration of MIT but we thought we believe that MIT should use technology
to enhance the core educational experience and by that at MIT a mean a
residential-based university where we teach relatively small numbers of students in intensive
ways that doesn't mean doing something different doesn't make sense for another University or another organization but
one of the key findings and and recommendations of this group is that what MIT should do is leverage the
opportunities technology provides to enhance what it's already doing that we
shouldn't become a global distance learning University with millions of students simultaneously for example that
may make sense for some organizations certainly the open university in the United Kingdom was founded on that as
their basic model but given mit's core strengths and core abilities we decided
that what it made sense is to do focus on two major things uh and basically
these res essentially mean stretching certain barriers or certain areas that we're now working in first uh we should
launch uh an enhanced version of our current research and development issues in educ educational technology and what
we have seen at MIT in the last year or two since this recommendation was made is a steady ramp up of the types and
Innovation sort of the level of activity in educational Technology Innovation and we now have far more
initiatives certainly many more than I've shown you in this brief presentation uh and we've been able to
get funding to do a wider range of things to explore different opportunities for improving our oncampus
educational experience for our students the second is something that's a little more subtle and that is to find
different ways to use Technologies to basically stretch the boundaries of what
it means to learn at MIT uh at its extreme one might think of an undergraduate education as a
four-year initiation into a lifelong Club right now students tend to think I
come to University and I leave the university and for many of them their sole contact is when they get alumni
newsletters and solicitations for donations that is for many students today the university EXP experience is
highly bounded within a 4-year interval we're fairly convinced that
that's not really the best model that particularly for our students who are intensively involved over their
lifetimes in engineering and Technology over about well over about two-thirds of our students undergraduate students
major in engineering and roughly 20% more or less major in science these are
fields that change rapidly and what the students have learned in their four-year
undergraduate experience will be to a large extent outdated particularly the the base
knowledge the facts of course what we really hope is they've learned a way to learn that will last them a lifetime and
so what we're trying to do now is to shift uh into much more activity to provide opportunities for LIF learn
lifelong learning we've been working with our alumni association uh we have a
concept called knowledge updates that provide opportunities for Learners
beyond the four-year experience we also have been trying to find ways to use
technology to make it easier for students to be off the campus at various times MIT has embarked on a Exchange
program with Cambridge University uh that allow that will eventually have at least 50 of our students there and 50 of
our their students here and part of what makes that possible is the ability to
take courses MIT also has a large program with the National University of Singapore and nanyang Technological
University something called the Singapore MIT Alliance that's using Technologies we've been looking at
various options uh for programs that we have now under study uh one is these
flexible educational options lifelong learning I've talked about we also think it's important to extend some of the
Computing capabilities we have on campus to the larger community of Learners and
they have a variety of things uh that we have been planning and working on to find ways to extend out the digital
infrastructure of the university the libraries and other digital resources it turns out there's a lot of complexity
that is both technological in nature what happens when we have uh 10 times as many people who are part of our digital
Community as we have now and also frankly legal and uh economic the
libraries for example have licenses for a variet of digital materials not all of
which can be provided outside the campus because of the licensing agreements we have with various providers of those
resources well in the class session that I'll be giving that uh Professor mea's
course I will be talking more about these and others and I hope to stimulate a discussion if you want more
information on the slide or as my contact information and you can contact me and when we do have the class I hope
to have an active and and Lively discussion about some of these issues look forward to talking to you
